And the sign of it when it is from a section of the stomach, because it makes something to happen from its own beginning with a sudden severe pain: and it is an appendage different, appearing under the skin near by; and this is because of the exit of the intestine, and its course towards the exterior of the stomach.
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	And sometimes it emerges with the intestine worm: and this is called the intestinal worm, and also the scabbird: and sometimes it occurs with windy conditions.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	And sometimes it runs into the intestine stool, and holds there; and is with that a painful disease of the sick: because it makes happen bad pain, especially when pressed.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	And in the care of creatures with the suffering of this condition with iron is fear: why must we be cautious of accidents in it.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	And the method of operation is, that you command the sick person to reduce his intestine by hand into his own hollowed interior, if he obeys you.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	Then the patient is turned over onto his back over his own shoulder between your hands, and he raises his legs.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	Then you extend the skin that follows the skin to the upper part, and dry the skin of the testicles all along its length.
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then you tie him in with two bands of the split at his lips, according to how much you need to open the split with them: and the cut should be made according to the quantity, so that an egg can come out of it.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then you scrape off the scrotum, and what is under the skin of the testicles, until when the scrotal membrane is removed, it becomes hard from every part: then you insert your finger into the place that follows the testicle, into the place that is between the scrotal membrane, which is under the skin, and between the scrotal membrane again, without the adhesion that is on the posterior part.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then you move with your right hand into the inside of the skin of the testicles: and with that, you stretch the scrotal membrane upwards, with your left hand: and you raise the egg with the membrane to the section: and command the servant, to stretch the egg upwards: and you release the adhesion, which is behind the completion of the solution.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And with your fingers, search that there is nothing there from the intestine rolled up in the scrotal membrane hard.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If, however, something is found from that (the intestine), then push it into the lower abdomen.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then take the awl, in which there is a thick thread, made from ten threads of linen; and insert it into the last siphon, that is, the tunic, which is under the testicles, after the cut: then incise the extremities that emerge from the thread until they are four threads.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then compose some of them above others with a figure which is in the form of a cross; and tie them to each other with the tunic, because it is under the ligament of the testicles which is strong, so that no part can send anything to them from the vessels that nourish them, lest something warm fall upon them.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And again put the second ligament outside the first one, at a distance of less than two fingers from it.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after those two ligaments release them from the tunic, which is under the skin of the testicles, to a size equivalent in magnitude to the width of a finger: and incise the whole remainder according to its roundness, and take out an egg from it.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	Then dry in the lower part of the skin-cutting of the testicles section, from which the blood flows, and the discharge: as we have said before.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then give him wool soaked in oil to swallow, and put it into the wound: and give him the ligament which we have mentioned.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when sometimes the tunic is cauterized with white stuff which we mentioned, after its incision, fearing a flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For it often happens that this.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And release the ligament until it falls away of its own accord.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	If however his case is delayed, then embrocation will be applied with warm water: and place over it the thing which we mentioned, until it falls.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	And then care for wounds with the rest of treatment for wounds until they are cured.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	On a poultice made from resin.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LXVI.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In this resin I did not see anyone who dared to try the treatment with iron.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And they said that it happens as we have narrated about the resin which is with wine.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Which is that you tie the cloth over the section with ease underneath it: then dry it in the middle and after that, you treat it further with what opens itself, until the cloth falls off: and care for the wound, as we have said, until it heals.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	On the separation that occurs in the groin.
Caput LXVII.	Chapter LXVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, as we have said, and the swelling is great, and it does not descend to the testicles anything from the intestines: and if it descends, that is little, and returns all within an hour: but if prolonged with it for some time, a fissure is added to the scrotum, until the intestines come down into the scrotum.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And it also happens that there is an issue with the extension of the scrotum, which is as we have said.
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	Which is that the scrotum extends because it becomes soft: then a wound forms and the swelling grows.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its treatment is with cauterization, as we have previously said.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And sometimes it is treated with iron, in this manner: and there is, as the patient lies supine on his back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry a place of rupture's afterthought and its prominent part, divided by length, according to the size of three fingers.
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then bind a ligature around the lip and, those that are under the skin, until when the silver ribbon is uncovered, which is under the skin following it.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take a radius and place the latter on top of the prominent part with the silver ribbon, and press it deeply into the stomach.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then sew two prominent places on the extremity of the radius with silver, and join one to the other by a single suture; then remove the extremity of the radius.
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut the silver ribbon completely, nor stretch the skin, nor any other thing, as you know from having knowledge of treating intestinal stones.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then treat that wound with the treatment of wounds.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When therefore you cut the thread, clean it up and restore the wound until it is consolidated.
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	For the silver becomes contracted, and not added to the prominence of rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And cauterization is better in this place: because it is closer to salvation.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	¶ On softening of the skin of the testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter 68.
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	The skin of the testicles is often softened in some people, because of which the flesh between them softens and its appearance is corrupted.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for him who is being treated for this, to make the weak one lie on his back and cut the entire skin that has been softened over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	And then take two lips with suture: and if it wishes, he should first soften the softness of the skin with three or four sutures, and a firm suture.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then treat the remaining wounds with care, as long as they heal and the threads fall out.
¶ De Castratione.	¶ On Castration.
Caput LXIX.	Chapter 69.
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is forbidden by law in our land: and for this reason it was allowed to me not to remember it in this book of mine; and it is not necessary to remember it, except for two reasons.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	One of which is, that it should be known in the knowledge of a doctor when asked about it: and that he may know the cure for those who have had it.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And the other reason is, that we often need castration of certain animals for our necessities by means of it, such as oxen, hyraxes, and cats, and similar animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I therefore say that castration is performed in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by attrition.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by fissure and cutting.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In those that are performed by attrition, the operation is the life of the procedure: which we do, that we make the animal sit in warm water, until its testicles soften and relax, and hang down: then beat them with your hand, until they dissolve and do not appear under touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In castration, however, by fissure and cutting, it is necessary to hold the animal down and press its testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie the suspensory ligament and cut off its top section through every egg until when there are two eggs: then cut them off after you have cleaned both of them, and do not leave anything else on it except for a very fine thread that is above the vessel.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than the one that is done by attrition: because attrition perhaps leaves something from the testicles, so that the animal desires coitus.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	¶ On the treatment of the hermaphrodite, two methods.
Caput LXX.	Chapter LX.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	The hermaphrodite is from the genitals, according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them is because it appears in the fact that it follows a space, or in the fat of the testicles, in which there is an interval between the two testicles, a figure like that of a woman's vulva, in which there are hairs: and sometimes urine runs from it because it is in the fat of the testicles.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	In women however there is one species, and it is a vulva like that of a woman over the pubic bone, just as the testicles of a man are small entirely, protruding to the outside: for whose one is like the penis of a man, and two like two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the treatment of the three species, two from the testicles and one from women, is this: because it is necessary to cut the added flesh until they release their impression.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then care for those with the treatment of the remaining wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	In the second species of men, from which urine is discharged, which is in the fat of the testicles, there is no operation, nor is its treatment complete.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On the incision of Tentigintis, and the fatty flesh of the vulvas of women.
Caput LXXI.	Chapter LXXI.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The warts perhaps are added to a natural thing, until it becomes foul and its appearance is deformed: and sometimes it swells so much in certain women that it expands as if it were flesh, and goes as far as coitus.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	You must therefore hold the excess of Tentigintis by hand or with a lancet, and cut into it: and not to make a final cut, especially at the deep root: lest there be a flow of blood.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat this cure with the treatment of wounds, until it is healed.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	The flesh is cut open, which is the flesh that is born in the maternal orifice, until it fills it: and perhaps comes out to the exterior according to the shape of the tail: and for this reason some call it a condition of the tail.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	You must therefore cut her as we cut a wart, and treat her, until she is healed.
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	On the treatment of the Al-Resi warts, which are unperforated vulvas in women.
Caput LXXII.	Chapter LXXII.
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The Al-Resi is, as if it were an unperforated vulva in a woman, or a small hole.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And it can be either natural or acquired.
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	Accidentalis is caused by an existing disease, and it itself arises either from the added flesh or from a small thread, or a point: and it forms either at a deep spot in the matrix, or in its sides, or above it, or below it. It prevents sexual intercourse and conception, childbirth, and perhaps menstruation as well.
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	And knowledge of this is obtained by the appearance of obstetrics, if it seems close to the eyelid.
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If, however, it is not apparent, then seek it with your fingers, or with a stick.
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If, however, the eyelid is split from a small scratch beneath the lower lid: then cut it open, and tear it apart.
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is as if you put two wool pads.
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then place your fingers on both sides of the hands together, and have the woman lie on her back with her legs stretched out.
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then stretch out both eyelids with force, until the small scratch is torn and the eyelid opens.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then take the wool and soak it in oil, and place it on that spot. And cook the woman every day, so that the place does not heal by another means.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If the scratch is thick and dense, then you must cut it open with a scissor resembling a broad-leafed myrtle leaf.
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If the eyelid is made of flesh that has come out, then suspend it with a thread and cut it: and have you the medicinals which will stop the flow of blood without cutting, such as acacia, and dragon's blood, and this mixture combined with alum.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then administer a large syringe made of lead, so that the wound does not heal quickly, and hold it in for several days: and then administer licorice from dry linen, thereafter complete the treatment until healing takes place.
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when they are born with other flesh's flesh, it is therefore necessary that they be cut according to this method: because there is no cancer of the cord, for a cancerous condition does not exist in the womb, let there be no opposition with iron altogether.
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	On the care of hemorrhoids, Athelhel, and the reddening of Butor's warts in women.
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter 73
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are indeed the opening of the veins, until blood flows abundantly out of them.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When therefore hemorrhoids constrict, they become thickened: and I have already said in the division of their kinds, and the signs of them: and I shall say here what receives cure from them, and what does not.
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I therefore say that hemorrhoids which are in the orifice of the matrix and do not appear to the sense, then there is no cure with iron.
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Those which are from them that fall on the matrix over which sense falls can be cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is therefore necessary to admit a woman into a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then extend Athelhel with his ligatures or rough cloth, and strike them out from their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then sprinkle over them near the flow of blood from one of their scraped incisions without mutilation, such as acacia and dragon's blood and such like them.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then cause her to push one foot against the wall for an hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Afterwards put her in a cold water.
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the flow of blood has persisted: then make her sit on a decoction of sumach, and granated comfrey, and galls, and like.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take the meal of barley and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make an ointment from it on her back.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If therefore blood is cut with it, this is good; and if not, make a binding on the back with wens, and nipples, without scarification.
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool and immerse it in the juice of tartar, or the juice of arnoglossum, or the juice of glanum, that is, alaula, with Pontic wine, and make a binding on the heel.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When therefore the swelling subsides, then cure the place with ointments, until it is healed.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	Albucasis's skin was rough like the head of an ass, and had a rough appearance.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is therefore necessary to make an incision that appears from it, as I said earlier, equally; and treat the same, until it is healed.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	On the peritonitis that occurs in the matrix.
Caput LXXIIII.	Head LXXIV.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Many species occur in the matrix, such as tumors, stone cysts, ulcers, scabs, and herpetic ulcers, painful swellings, fistulas, hemorrhoids, warts, and boils, and hot swellings.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I have already said all these diseases and their kinds, and the signs of them, and their treatments divided: it is necessary that I say in this treatise about the hot swelling that occurs in the matrix, which happens from swellings that collect pus, and how to know by its opening with iron.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is therefore necessary to consider.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	Then if the pain of the swelling in its onset is sharp with percussion, and inflammation, and fever; and you see it to be red, if anything falls on top of it, then do not wait for perforation of it: treat it with it as it suits the healing of the matrix, until when the sharpness of the accidents subsides.
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then you must make the woman sit on a bench that is over two benches, and she reclines or it is placed over her back, and her feet are brought to the lower part of her belly: and her hips should be stretched out, and she places her arms under her breasts, and ties both with the ligament suitable for that.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then the woman-birther sits on the right side, and she administers the instrument by which the aperture of the uterus is opened.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose form comes to them that are posterior.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary when you administer this instrument, to tie with cord the uterus of a woman, so that it may not enter by the instrument more than the depth of the uterus, and injure the weak one.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	If however the instrument is more than the depth, then you must put wool over the covering of the depth of the uterus: so that the entrance of the entire instrument may be prohibited in the depth of the uterus: and you must place the vertebra, which runs on the upper side of the instrument, so that it holds the instrument and turns the vertebra, until the depth of the uterus is opened.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When therefore the opening appears and is touched with one's hand, and it is soft and smooth: then you must cut the same off at its head with a saw.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When therefore the discharge is evacuated, then you must put on a ligature, submerged in rose oil or green oil, in which there is some congealing: and place the ligature, and draw out the section from the depth of the uterus.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place it outside over the uterus, and over the clean wool covering submerged in water, in which bolls are boiled.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	And afterwards it is treated with an ointment that is suitable for it, until it heals.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the matrix and wound are cleaned, so that a poultice is applied with water and honey: then with water in which the root of the mallow or long Aristolochia has been boiled: then it returns to the ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	But if the wound is hidden within the matrix, then you must avoid treating it with iron or, indeed, treat it as we said in the division.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	On the Doctrine of Childbirth, how they are treated for living embryos, following an unnatural form.
Caput Lxxu.	Head LXII.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the obstetrician to first recognize the natural form of childbirth.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	From these signs, therefore, you will know that when you see a woman compressed towards the lower parts, and she desires to smell the air, and is relieved above her where there is labor of birth, and hastens the exit of the embryo: then you will know that this delivery is according to the natural form, and it is the head coming out over its own, and in turn with it: or suspended, hanging from the navel.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	So when you see these signs, then it is necessary that the navel of hers be compressed, so that the embryo descends quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it descends over its head, the afterbirth follows with it, and is cleansed of those superfluous things by good purification.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	But whatever is outside this birth is unnatural and shameful.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For sometimes the fetus emerges over its feet, and its body emerges before its head, and its feet and hands one by one: or its head and hand emerge: or its abdomen emerges: and perhaps it turns on to its neck, and similar things from unnatural forms.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is necessary therefore for the obstetrician to be prudent and subtle in all these matters, and to beware of error and folly: and I am showing all forms from them, and how the mind is disposed towards it, and signifying it through this very thing, and setting it upon it.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus emerges over its head through natural expulsion, and that woman is troubled by it, and giving birth is difficult for her, and you see the virtue of hers already weakened: then seat her on a stool, or hold her tightly by women; and pour down upon her the woolly vapour of the fenugreek decocted, and with moist olive oil.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the obstetrician shall insert a small instrument, called sponula, between her fingers, and feel with it secondly, and prick it with her nail until it flows out from within her with moisture: and press upon the woman's abdomen until the fetus descends.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not descend, then it is necessary that the woman be treated with a dressing made of fenugreek mucilage, mixed with sasa oil.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then prescribe for her afterwards that she be compressed, so that it is compacted: and have her spit on her compresses with honey, and tie up her jaws and nose at the same hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	For the fetus will immediately emerge.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus emerge first, it is necessary that you reduce them with ease and graduality.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If it does not obey at the entrance, then place the woman on a stool, and raise her legs upwards: then strike the stool upon the earth: and hold the woman tightly, so that she will not fall at the concussion.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If however the hands do not emerge and the fetus dies, then cut them open and extract the remaining fetus: and bind its hand with a cloth, and extract it with evenness: for he himself will emerge.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The outcome of the fetus over its foot.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus emerges over its own feet, then it is necessary that they push them upwards: afterwards the fetus gradually changes direction: finally it equilibrates itself.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then take one of its feet and stretch it out gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When therefore they go down to the hips, then order that it be compressed and have a compression made with a cushion: for it will come out if God wills.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if it does not come out as we have narrated, then reduce the fetus gradually until you place it in the natural form.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For when he comes out with ease.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	But if it is prohibited with him as we have narrated: then take from the albumen of the bird and oil sesame, and gum unctuous, and strike all over with good mortar pounding: afterwards put a linen strip on it, and below the belly of hers.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make it sit in warm water until it gets a temperature.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When therefore you see that the lower parts are already warm, then make it sit on myrrh: and put it upon itself.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When therefore it holds steady for one hour, then make it sit on a bed.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make it stifle: and tie its own nose and mouth: and press the lower part of its belly gently.
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the heat will come out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The outcome of the fetus over the knee and hand.
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When he emerges in this form, then he should gradually insert his hands into it.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman is laid upon her back over her neck, and her feet hang down to the lower parts: and she lies lying upon a couch, and covers herself with her hands.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then he presses above her chest gradually.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then he removes what is under her feet from the armpits until it is prepared at the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not emerge, then take her feet and move them with a great movement.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then press what is above the navel gradually until the fetus rises to the upper parts.
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then he inserts his hands and equates the fetus gradually; and commands the woman to compress herself until the fetus emerges.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The exit of the fetus is latitudinally hanging from his hands.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	He should insert his hand again.
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If he cannot reduce her, then he should lift the woman and make her walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she cannot walk, then make her lie upon the couch and strike her thighs with great force.
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then he administers the liniment which you prepared from the mucilages.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she takes him out, then make her sit upon a seat.
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then he should study the reduction of his hands and equate the fetus according to its natural shape; and make the woman snort and command her to compress herself until she emerges.
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus exits over its neck, with its hands outstretched, and its face towards its mother's back.
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	It is necessary for the obstetrician to grasp the hand of the fetus, then slowly retract it, and set it in place with facility.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	Then when it is set in place, he will put over the wound that we have previously described with olive oil and mucilage.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then instruct him to move it gradually.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done that, then make her sit on a seat, and instruct her to lean towards the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then instruct her to press herself in: and make her yawn with the compresses.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The exit of the prepared fetus is made on the side.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it comes down to the matrix's opening in this manner with a second, then cut the second with your finger until it is drained of moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If therefore the fetus is suspended over its face and neck, then cut her from the navel: so that it will not be retained and will die.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus into its cavities until you place it as is necessary: and instruct the woman to press herself a few times: for he himself will emerge with a light exit.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The exit of twins or many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born, and sometimes even three and four.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	But that is unusual and rarely occurs.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Five are things outside of nature, and they do not live at all. And although they multiply, they contain only one, and separate them by a siphon, distinguishing between them as bound to the navel of each of their own.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And when they emerge as a single entity, like a newborn emerges from one birth naturally and easily, but some emerge through an ill-fated outlet, as we have narrated.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If some of them are difficult to pass through the birth and arrive at what we said from unnatural figures, then cure them as we have narrated: and let a skilful midwife be present, who will do what she does with ease and slowness, and devise according to all shapes that is prepared for her by her own ingenuity towards health.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remembrance of what is formed in the womb from embryos, and are aborted.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	At times a single one is formed in the womb, and two, and three, and four, and five, and six, and seven, and many ten: and it has already been verified by me that when a woman gives birth to seven, and fifteen others, all formed.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	What was done through the measurement of the glorious wise man.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	This is therefore that everything should be in the science of obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps however, it will lead to that similar thing of his: opposes therefore to him what is necessary.
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	About the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter 76.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you cure a dead fetus with what I said about the division from medicine, and it does not emerge, and you must use an operation with your hand, then you should consider.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If the woman is therefore sane in virtue and not with any accident from which she is feared to be ruined: then it must that the woman lies on her back, upon her back, and her head bent downwards, and her legs raised: and the servant must hold her from two sides, or bind her to the bed, so that her body shall not be taken out at the extraction of the fetus.
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the mouth of the uterus with oil from olives wet with gauze and fenugreek, and flaxseed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then the midwife anoints her own hand with these oils and gauzes, then inserts it into the uterus with ease.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then seek out with her where the navel of the fetus is located, and suitable places for it.
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider therefore at that time, if the fetus is prepared to descend over its head: then fasten the navel into its eyes, or its neck, or its mouth, or on its palate, or under its beard, or in its lock, or in nearby costal places, and beneath the navel itself, or near the hypocundrium.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If however its descent is over its feet, then into the pelvic bone and its middle costs.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it must be that she holds the navel with her right hand: and puts its curve between the space of the left-hand fingers: and inserts it with ease, and fastens the navel in some one of those places which we have mentioned, until it comes to the empty place.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then fastens the second or third navel as an opposite, or if needed: so that there is equal contraction and not deviate to one side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then the extension is stretched out equally, and it should not be a straight extension only, but rather it should move to all parts, so that its exit may be alleviated: as it happens with the tooth during its extraction.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it should also be taken into consideration that which is between those things, so that the extension may be softened.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	Which if retained from it, then it is necessary that an obstetrician should apply some fingers with oil to those parts and introduce them from the part, so that they may turn back along with what is retained.
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If therefore a part of the fetus is expelled, then the nails are changed to a place that is higher: do this until the whole fetus has been expelled.
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If therefore the hand is expelled before others and it cannot be returned because of its constrictions: then a cloth should be wrapped around it.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then draw her out until when the whole comes out, cut or bind her at the joint of the foot, or on the cubit: and so you should do in your other hand, and in two feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If however the head of the fetus is large, or a constriction occurs at its exit, or there is water accumulated on its head: then an instrument should be inserted between the fingers of the Spatumile with spines, and cut with it the head, and draw out the water: or break it with the instrument that is called Almisdac: whose form comes according to the forms of the other instruments in the chapter which follows this.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Similarly, if the fetus has a large head nature, then it is necessary to cut away its algae: or draw it out with the misdaç, as we said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then grasp the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	Which if the head were to be cut out and bound with a forceps: then a discovery is made, until the moisture which is in the chest is spilled.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If however it does not adhere or yield to the exit: then cut off the head forcefully, as is possible to you.
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If the lower part of the stomach is swollen or has hydrops: then it must be perforated, until the moisture drains from it.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If a fetus is on its feet, then the attraction of it is easy, and its direction towards the ribs of the uterus is gentle.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If however it is bound about the stomach or breast: then it must be grasped with a cloth that you have wrapped around your hand: and the belly or breast must be felt until what is inside them is drained.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If the other parts are retained and the head returns: then the obstetrician inserts his left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If then the ribs of the uterus are open: then the obstetrician inserts his hand into the depth of the uterus, and seeks with it the head, and grasps it with his fingers up to the ribs of the uterus: then he inserts one or two hooks into him, and grasps him with them.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the ribs of the uterus are bound due to swelling that occurs within it: then it is not necessary to labor over it, but rather to administer a discharge of moist and oily substances: and apply poultices: and sit in water which softens and moistens.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is on its side: then it is possible for it to be retained. Then what we said about the living fetus should be administered.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do that, then it should be struck with a blunt instrument and removed.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And you must not leave anything of the second incision inside entirely.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When therefore you complete your operation, then administer what we said about the cold sores that occur on the matrix.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If there should be a flow of blood, then it should be directed to the stifting waters, and administer the rest of the treatment.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have already seen a woman, whose womb was dead with a fetus: then she became pregnant again upon that same flesh, afterwards another fetus died.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	So it happened to her after a long time that an ulcer appeared at the navel of hers, and it swelled until it was open: and she began to discharge pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was summoned therefore for her cure, and I treated her at a long time: but the wound did not become consolidated.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I therefore placed upon it from some of those poultices with strong attractive power: and it came out from the place teeth.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then after a few days she had another tooth come out.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I was amazed therefore from that point on, since there is no bone in the womb.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	Therefore I thought, because they were dead fetuses made of bones.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I therefore examined the wound and extracted many bones from a woman who was in better condition than she had been at that time: and she had already lived for such a long time, and she sent out from the place little pus.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I myself had not firmly believed this thing to be so, unless because there is knowledge of it, and aid for that which the artisan medic is accustomed to administer with his hand in the cure.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	On the necessary forms of instruments for the extraction of a fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter LXXVII.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here, the lower part is the form of the Tightener, with which the books are equalized, having two vertiges equally on both ends of two pieces of wood.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	However, this vertige must be so subtle as to be on a level with the tightener: and it is thus made, either of ebony or of wood busse.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	And let the width of all wood be nearly two fingers, and the edge of each one is almost a finger, and the length of both are a palm and half, and in the middle of the two woods there are two additional pieces of the same kind of wood, which have already been fixed on both sides, whose length is half a palm and less: and their width is nearly two fingers or less.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	And these two additional pieces are inserted into the bone of the matrix, so that it may open with them when you turn on both vertiges.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the Vertige which opens the matrix.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another form similar to that, more subtle and lighter.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	Let it be made of ebony or busse wood, according to the likeness of a forceps.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	However, on its extremity there are two additional pieces, as you see here above: and the length of all their pieces is nearly a palm: and their width is nearly two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When therefore you open the matrix with it, then sit a woman on the bed, with her feet hanging down, and that which is opened between her thighs.
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then insert those two additions together into the matrix: and you are holding the lower extremity of the instrument between its hips.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, as you do with forceps, equally in proportion to the quantity of which you make an opening in the uterus, until the obstetrician does what he desires.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The form of vertigo which they have said is different from the one called the "Impelling Form", by means of which the fetus is pushed.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The form of a foul act whereby the great head is crushed: and it is similar to forceps, which have teeth at the end, as you see.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And when it is made twisted, as the forceps are in this form, as you see, which have teeth like saw-toothed teeth, whereby it is struck and crushed.
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The form of a foul act whereby the small head is crushed.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The form having a spine with one spiny hair.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The form having two spines.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The form of forceps which have saw-toothed teeth, by means of which the fetus's head is crushed.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The form of a scythe-like instrument having two ends for cutting the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The form of two longer scythes.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are used for all the procedures, and the more their varieties multiply, and they are prepared by the craftsman, the swifter is it to its operation, and taller to men, on account of its size.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	Therefore do not despise them, but rather prepare one for yourself from them.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	They are inexcusable because their need.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	On the second extraction.
Caput LXXVIII.	Chapter LXXXVIII.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second is retained at childbirth, then you should order that it be removed from a weak one, so that it may retain its breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make her sneeze with the application of condisi: and tie your hand over her nose and mouth.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If so then it is good.
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then take a bowl and perforate an opening in the abdominal covering: and put into it herbs which open the mouth of the uterus, such as licorice root, rue, and anise, and chamomile, and senna, and cassia, and lignum centaurium: take all these herbs, or some of them, and submerge them in water, and place them over the fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then put a linen band over the opening of the bowl and the other extremity into the uterus: and hold it until vapor comes out to the closeness of the uterus.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make her sneeze again, as we said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	The second will come out with ease.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If however it remains after this treatment and does not come out: then order the obstetrician to dip his hand in sesame oil, or mucilage of alum.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then introduce it into the vulva and seek for the second.
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When therefore he finds her, then take her and extend her gradually.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If it happens to be adherent to the deep surface of the matrices, then let him insert his hand, as we have said, until when he finds the Second (i.e. the second incision), and pulls it out gradually according to straightness, so that it does not fall into the matrix at the greater attraction: it is necessary, however, that with ease and facility he turns around to both the right and left side: then add up the amount of the attraction.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	For this is obeyed then, and preserved, and freed from the adherence.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	Which if the matrix bone is curved, as we have already said: treat it with scratching, and from the medicine of the earl's jar with herbs.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If however it does not come out with all that we have said, then beware that you do not tire yourself over it on the repetition of extractions.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	But it is necessary that what comes out to the matrix bone from it be tied to the wife's thigh.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then dress it with the tetrapharmacos ointment.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	For this itself would putrefy it after a day, and dissolve it, and bring it out.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	However when it has putrefied, then let it be lifted out from it a foul odor to the stomach and head, and harm that sick one.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	It is therefore necessary to administer suitable fumigations to it.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancients have already been experienced in the fumigation of nasturtium and dried fig.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The form of the instrument by which the woman is fumigated under the retention of the Second and menstrual incisions.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	Let it be made of the root of alcama, or of the sap, and a limb large over fire shall be placed upon it; and an ointment must be put on the nails. It must hold it until that ointment is consumed, then another one.
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	On the cure of the unperforated intestine.
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter LXXIX.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born with unperforated intestines, and the gallbladder of these infants is already inflamed.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	So it is necessary, that the midwife pierces that gallbladder with her finger: and if she cannot, she must pierce it herself with a sharp instrument: and she should be cautious not to touch it.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then place over it a cloth soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with ointments until it is healed.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If however it is found that it is inflamed, then place a leaden cannula in its urethra for many days, and remove it when the child wishes to urinate.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And now inflammation of the intestine has occurred even from the consolidation of the wound or the suppuration.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	So it is necessary that the consolidation be cut open, and then it should be treated as we have said for the cure.
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	On the cure of fistulas that occur at the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Chapter LXXX.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas that occur at the lower part are nodules and swelling that occurs near the anus externally, or in a space of one part, and it is a single fistula, or there are multiple.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	Since then, that Nodation swells, opens up and runs out of it with watery whiteness or subtle pus.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And when they are punctures from within that fistula.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	So they are recognized by what comes out of it from vomiting and flatulence, when the sick person vomits, and perhaps there is worm.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And they are fistulas when they penetrate in space until the vesicle and up to the tendons.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are that penetrate until the joint of the pelvis and up to the knee knot.
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From that point where the penetrating fistula goes up to the anus, it is also known whether there is one which does not penetrate and even one which should be inserted by your finger into the anus: and insert a delicate probe into the fistula of air or iron when it's not twisted.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	If there is twisting in it, then insert a delicate probe of lead or a bullet from the hairs of the horse's nails into it, until you feel the probe or the bullet with your finger.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you don't feel the very thing, nor anything comes out through an opening from vomiting or flatulence, nor a worm as I said, then you know it is not penetrating. Proceed therefore to curement.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula is penetrating up to the vesicle or the tendon of urine: then its signification is the outlet of urine from it, and prohibition of this that it may consolidate with medicines.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If it is penetrating up to the joint of the pelvis or into the bone of the pelvis: then its signification is that the probe will go there, if there is no twisting up to the bones: and discovery of pain around the part, and that pus always comes out from it: and that it does not heal with this medicine, nor consolidates with ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And in these fistulas of all kinds there is no cure at all; and their cure is toil and uncertainty from foolish doctors who devise this.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	But in those that are not penetrating and are not old, a cure is hoped for with stitches: as I tell you, and as I have already proved: and it is so, that the sick man should lie between your hands on his back: and lift up his legs until above the hips of himself; and the hips of him should be bent towards the belly of himself.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then they should introduce a lead or air plug into the fistula, if it is twisted, until you know where it goes and try.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If however the sick man feels it around the anus, then you should put your finger into his anus.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If therefore you feel that your finger has penetrated through itself into the fistula, except for what you feel between your finger and the anus or flesh, then you are certainly sure that it is penetrating: not to be labored over because there is no cure for it, as we have said.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	However they say that the flesh heals in some people and from the medicine by which they hope a remedy, it is so that thin fire cauterium according to the size of the fistula, as before, should be inserted into the fistula, until it passes around the anus.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then do that again twice or three times until you know, for those tissues have been burned and are now all hardened and thin, like the beak of a bird or the feathers of a chicken.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then the cure is to wrap linen around the incision in butter until those tissues come out that have been burned; then the cure is again with ointments that produce meat and consolidate.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If therefore it is cured, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, then it will never be cured with any other treatment.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if it discharges itself and does not reach the distance of your finger, which is at the anus, between that and the rectum, a thick membrane of flesh or faeces, and you see a fistula following the surface of the skin, then dry the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and you will cut with cutting as it is in the fistula until its end where its extremity reaches, and the tenta is liberated and falls.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then cleanse those filtered flesh parts which resemble the beaks of birds or reeds, so that there is nothing left from them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however the blood clings to you and loosens between you and the operation, so that it separates those flesh parts: then it is better what happens, and more speedy relief, to cauterize her with fire, or with sharp medicine.
